review.body:
First book by for me by this author

I enjoyed this book. I felt that at times it was too simplistic, juvenile may be? Will I buy the next book? Yes and I look forward to reading it

Not really what I was expecting but it was still an alright book. It wasn't particularly long so probably wasn't worth the money and I felt a lot of the examples containing the numbers mentioned were like that out of coincidence, not because they meant anything special- more like the number is co...

Two legs bad. Four legs good.
If Donald Trump wins, don't say you weren't warned.
Great collection of short essays by leading spiritual thinkers on the corporal and spiritual acts of mercy. A helpful meditation tool.
One word. Troy. And where can I find me one?

book.title: Lord of the Flies
book.edition_information: Penguin Great Books of the 20th Century

review.body: This wasn't at all what I was expecting but a really good book. The way the author captures the minds of children is amazing and while some parts don't seem particularly realistic I still found myself hooked. This was a nice book to read on a long train journey and isn't long and dragged out like...
Slightly biased, of course, as I wrote it. But I do think you'll like it too.

Perfect for starting to learn the rules for my driving theory test that is upcoming. The pages of road signs were particularly useful and I'll continue to use this to memorise them up until my theory test. The price of this is also very good considering how much it helps.

book.title: Clients First: The Two Word Miracle

review.body: Because clients are people like anyone else, success when working with clients is fundamentally based on putting their interest first. By demonstrating honesty, competence and caring, you can set your company apart from the competition, while creating support networks that will keep you afloat ev...

book.title: A Memory of Violets: A Novel of London's Flower Sellers

review.body: Heartwarming.
Everyone should read this book. Then everyone should write to Congress about giving Snowden amnesty.

Unlike the usual kind of books of 100 places you need to visit, this book is interesting to highlight the alternative: those you will never visit. Though some places were probably not that interesting and seemed to make up the 100, it's still worth a read!

For the first half of this book reading was a great effort and I not only found the language difficult to understand (the book is now celebrating it's 200th anniversary) but I found the characters hard to keep up with and found myself needing a who's who list. After that the book got better and I...

book.title: Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda

review.body: The voice felt so authentic and relatable!

book.title: A Gathering of Shadows (Shades of Magic, #2)

review.body: Would be five stars but the ending left me so disappointed.

"Few non-Western cities have penetrated our consciousness like Benghazi, Libya, following the 2012 attack on the American mission there, yet most of us know little about that city’s recent past. The English-language publication of Alessandro Spina’s grand, historical novel about twentieth-century...

book.title: Baby I'm In (Honky Tonk Angels Book 3)

review.body:
This is a sweet story about Liz, a women trying to prove something to her father and trying to make her own way. Her father is rich and not remorseful and actually willing to hurt or kill people to get his own way, but Liz doesn't know the half of it. Yet.
Liz gets a job as a jockey, to ride a hor...

This was a hilarious fast read for only 20p. I don't think it's worth it if you're paying full price because it really is very short. But there are a lot of funny passages and I'm sure the photos look a lot better when in colour and not on Kindle!

book.title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks

review.body: One of the saddest things I've ever read.

book.title: The Intimate Adventures Of A London Call Girl

review.body: Really funny book to read and I think I prefer reading it now the identity of the author is known as it makes it feel a lot more real. Probably one of my favourite diary-style books that I've read in recent years and it's such a different book as well. Not many books are on this subject matter!
